oasis-e-cognitive Start of Care: A1218083010191 TherapyEpisodes_SMK (731)

Psychiatric Worksheet

(C0100) Should Brief Interview for Mental Status (C0200-C0500) be Conducted? Attempt to conduct interview with all patients:




Brief Interview for Mental Status (BIMS)

Coding Tips

Nonsensical responses, incorrect answers, and questions the patient chooses not to answer should be coded as zero.

  • • The assessing clinician should track the reason for coding answers as zero because this information will be used later for the coding of the summary score in C0500.


Rules for stopping the BIMS interview before it is complete:

  • Stop the interview after completing (C0300C) "Day of the Week" if:
    • • All responses have been nonsensical (l.e., any response that is unrelated, incomprehensible, or incoherent; not informative with respect to the item being rated), OR
    • • there has been no verbal or written response to any of the questions up to this point, OR
    • • there has been no verbal or written response to some questions up to this point and for all others, the patient has given a nonsensical response.
  • If the interview is stopped, do the following:
    • • Code "-" in C0400A, C0400B, and C0400C.
    • • Code 99 in the summary score in C0500.

If all responses to C0200, C0300A, C0300B, and C0300C are 0 because answers are incorrect, continue interview.

Examples of Incorrect Answers, Refusals, and Nonsensical Responses
Guidance Code O is used to represent three types of responses: incorrect answers (unless the item itself provides an alternate response code), nonsensical responses, and questions the patient chooses not to answer (or "refusals"). Since zeros resulting from these three situations are treated differently when coding the summary score in C0500, the assessing clinician may find it valuable to track the reason for the zero reponse to aid in accurately calculating the summary score.
BIMS (C0200 - C0500)

(C0200) Repetition of Three Words Ask patient "I am going to say three words for you to remember. Please repeat the words after I have said all three. The words are: sock, blue, and bed. Now tell me the three words."

Specify Scoring Reason (required):





After the patient's first attempt, repeat the words using cues ("sock, something to wear, blue, a color, bed a piece of furniture"). You may repeat the words up to two more times.

(C0300) Temporal Orientation (Orientation to year, month, and day):

Ask patient: "Please tell me what year it is right now"

A. Able to report correct year

Specify Scoring Reason (required):





Ask patient: "What month are we in right now?"

B. Able to report correct month

Specify Scoring Reason (required):




Ask patient: "What day of the week is today?"

C. Able to report correct day

Specify Scoring Reason (required):



(C0400) Recall:

Ask patient: "Let's go back to an earlier question. What were those three words that I asked you to repeat?" If unable to remember a word, give cue (something to wear, a color, a piece of furniture) for that word.

A. Able to recall "sock"

Specify Scoring Reason (required):




B. Able to recall "blue"

Specify Scoring Reason (required):




C. Able to recall "bed"

Specify Scoring Reason (required):




(C0500) BIMS Summary Score Add scores for questions C0200-C0400 and fill in total score (00-15):

Unable to complete interview
Unable to calculate total score: If the reason for a 0 was scored on items the reason must be specified in order to accurately calculate the Total Score in C0500
(C1310) Signs and Symptoms of Delirium (from CAM©)

Code after completing Brief Interview for Mental Status and reviewing medical record

A. Acute Onset of Mental Status Change

Is there evidence of an acute change in mental status from the patient's baseline?

B. Inattention

Did the patient have difficulty focusing attention, for example, being easily distractible or having difficulty keeping track of what is being said?





C. Disorganized Thinking

Was the patient's thinking disorganized or incoherent (rambling or irrelevant conversation, unclear or illogical flow of ideas, or unpredictable switching from subject to subject)?





D. Altered level of consciousness

Did the patient have altered level of consciousness, as indicated by any of the following criteria?

  • Vigilant - startled easily to any sound of touch
  • Lethargic - repeatedly dozed off when being asked questions, but responded to voice or touch
  • Stuporous - very difficult to arouse and keep aroused for the interview
  • Comatose - could not be aroused




Adapted from: Inouye SK, et al. Ann Intern Med. 1990; 113: 941-948. Confusion Assessment Method. Copyright 2003, Hospital Elder Life Program, LLC. Not to be reproduced without permission

oasis-e-cognitive Start of Care 01/01/2024

(M1720) When Anxious (Reported or Observed Within the Last 14 Days):





(D0150) Patient Mood Interview (PHQ-2 to 9)
Say to patient: "Over the last 2 weeks, have you been bothered by any of the following problems?"
  • If symptom is present, enter Yes in Column 1, Symptom Presence.
  • If Yes in column 1, then ask the patient: "About how often have you been bothered by this?"
  • Read and show the patient a card with the symptom frequency choices.
  • Indicate response in column 2, Symptom Frequency.
    		•
    • 1. Symptom Presence

      0. No (enter 0 in Column 2)

      1. Yes (enter 0-3 in Column 2)

      9. No Response (leave Column 2 blank)
    • 2. Symptom Frequency

      0. No (Never or 1 day)

      1. 2 to 6 days (several days)

      2. 7-11 days (half or more of the days)

      3. 12-14 days (nearly every day)

    A. Little interest or pleasure in doing things

    1. Symptom Presence 2. Symptom Frequency

    B. Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless

    1. Symptom Presence 2. Symptom Frequency

    If either D0150A2 or D0150B2 (Symptom Frequency) is coded 7-11 Days (half or more of the days) or 12-14 days (nearly every day) CONTINUE asking the questions below. If not, END the PHQ interview.

    C. Trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much

    1. Symptom Presence 2. Symptom Frequency

    D. Feeling tired or having little energy

    1. Symptom Presence 2. Symptom Frequency

    E. Poor appetite or overeating

    1. Symptom Presence 2. Symptom Frequency

    F. Feeling bad about yourself - or that you are a failure or have let yourself or your family down

    1. Symptom Presence 2. Symptom Frequency

    G. Trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television

    1. Symptom Presence 2. Symptom Frequency

    H. Moving or speaking so slowly that other people could have noticed. Or the opposite - being so fidgety or restless that you have been moving around a lot more than usual

    1. Symptom Presence 2. Symptom Frequency

    I. Thoughts that you would be better off dead, or of hurting yourself in some way

    1. Symptom Presence 2. Symptom Frequency

    Copyright Pfizer Inc. All rights reserved. Reproduced with permission.

    (D0160) Total Severity Score Add scores for all frequency responses in Column 2, Symptom Frequency. Total score must be between 00 and 27.

    Unable to complete interview

    (D0700) Social Isolation: How often do you feel lonely or isolated from those around you?

    oasis-e-cognitive Start of Care 01/01/2024

    (M1745) Frequency of Disruptive Behavior Symptoms (Reported or Observed) Any physical, verbal, or other disruptive/dangerous symptoms that are injurious to self or others or jeopardize personal safety.






    Interventions
    *SN TO NOTIFY PHYSICIAN THIS PATIENT WAS SCREENED FOR DEPRESSION USING THE PHQ-2 SCALE AND MEETS CRITERIA FOR FURTHER EVALUATION FOR DEPRESSION
    SN to assess for changes in neurological status every visit
    SN to assess patient's communication skills every visit
    SN to instruct the on seizure precautions
    SN to instruct caregiver on orientation techniques to use when patient becomes disoriented
    MSW: OR visits, every 60 days for provider services
    MSW: OR visits, every 60 days for long term planning
    MSW: OR visits, every 60 days for community resource assistance
    Additional Orders:  
    Goals
    Patient will remain free from increased confusion during the episode
    The will verbalize understanding of seizure precautions
    Caregiver will verbalize understanding of proper orientation techniques to use when patient becomes disoriented
    Patient's community resource needs will be met with assistance of social worker
    Additional Goals:
